newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: N.Korean defector to arrive in S.Korea on Sunday.
newsitem.headline: N.Korean defector to arrive in S.Korea on Sunday.

text.p: A senior North Korean defector taking refuge in the Philippines will arrive in South Korea on Sunday, ending his 68-day odyssey, South Korean government sources said.
Hwang Jang-yop, the most senior Pyongyang official to flee the North, would be flown to South Korea on a special plane, the sources said on Saturday.

"You can expect an announcement tomorrow morning after Hwang Jang-yop leaves the Philippines," a government source said. "There will, of course, be another announcement after he arrives in our country."
Hwang was flown to a hideout in the Philippines on March 18 after arriving in South Korea's consulate in Beijing on February 12.

His exact whereabouts in the Philippines have remained a closely guarded secret since he was spirited out of Beijing after more than a month of negotiations between South Korean diplomats and Chinese officials.
Hwang, chief architect of North Korea's governing ideology of "juche", a creed of self-reliance, is expected to issue a statement on his arrival in Seoul, security officials here said.
Diplomats have said China, which fought alongside North Korea in the 1950-53 Korean War, tried to save face for its ally by demanding that Hwang stay in the Philippines for about one month.
Tensions between North and South Korea remain high, more than four decades after their war ended in a truce.

Seoul has indicated Hwang would arrive in a glare of publicity. South Korean information officials have told reporters they are arranging facilities for the media, including foreign journalists, to cover Hwang's arrival.
Hwang is seen by some Western officials as a man who might provide an insight into the state of Pyongyang's military and government as it grapples with an economic catastrophe.

Seoul officials said Hwang's departure from the Philippines would not be affected by the outcome of a meeting in New York where U.S. and South Korean diplomats have tried to win Pyongyang's unqualified agreement to join landmark four-nation peace talks, which include China.
North Korea failed to resume discussion with the United States and South Korea on Friday on a proposal for the talks, forcing the meeting to be delayed until Saturday.

The New York meeting was arranged to hear Pyongyang's formal response to a year-old U.S.-South Korean proposal for peace talks that would finally close the books on the 1950-53 Korean War by replacing the armistice with a peace treaty.
U.S. and South Korean delegates remained hopeful the North would respond positively to the talks.
Diplomats from the United States and the two Koreas held an an inconclusive day-long meeting on Wednesday.
U.S. officials said privately Pyongyang essentially accepted the peace talks proposal on Wednesday but then tied its acceptance to demands for additional food assistance.
Both Washington and South Korea maintain large-scale aid can be discussed once Pyongyang sits at the peace table.
